that the cost of a battery pack for LIBs will reach 100 USD per kWh by 2030, but more recent trends
show this could happen much earlier. For example, according to IEA, battery pack costs could be as
low as 80 USD per kWh by 2030

ing use of relatively inexpensive elements, which can
The main challenge these technologies face is in terms
of the cycle life. Out of the three, Li
S has already been used for applications in unmanned aerial
et al., 2017) due to relatively high specific energy (almost double the state of art
LIBs). However, even with low cycle life, Li
air hold good prospects for commercialisation
as range extender batteries for long

hicles that are typically used for
Alternative electricity storage technologies for heavy
previous section are driving the electrification of
their application to railways, aviation, ships,
and large vehicles faces challenges due to the higher power requirements of these applications. The use
of a capacitor with a higher power density than LIBs could be suitable for the electrification of such
vehicles. It is one of the solutions for regenera
ting large and instantaneous energy from regenerative
10,000 W/kg) than batteries. However, the energy density is poor (1

density, electrochemical double layer capacitors (EDLCs; supercapacitor) and hybrid capacitors (10
The highest energy density of the LIC system (100
140 Wh/kg in the research stage) are approaching
. Examples of effective use of capacitors include a 12 tonne truck with a capacitor
energy recovery system (KERS) that has been reported to save up to 32%
. Similarly, an EDLC bank applied to electric railwa
y systems has been shown to
result in a 10% reduction in power consumption per day
which capacitors are mounted on an electric bus for charging at a stop have been put into practical use,
. At the bus stop, the capacitor is charged at 600 kW for 10
~ 40 seconds, which provides enough power for 5 ~ 10 k
durable capacitors can achieve a longer life than LIB systems
Hybrid energy storage (HES) systems, which combine a capac
itor and a battery, achieve both high
power and high energy, solving problems such as capacity loss of the battery and self
capacitor. In these systems, the capacitor absorbs the steeper power, while the LIB handles the steady
by reducing the power loss of the EV to half. Furthermore, since the in
battery is suppressed, there is an improvement in the reliability of the LIB (Noumi et al., 2014). In a
hybrid diesel train, 8.2% of the regenerative energy is lost
